keyTakeAways: Christopher Moynihan, a former Capitol rioter, was pardoned by President Trump in early 2021 as part of a blanket pardon of over 1,500 individuals involved in the Jan. 6 Capitol riot.

Moynihan was arrested in October 2025 after allegedly threatening to kill U.S. House Minority Leader Hakeem Jeffries via text messages, including messages stating he would 'kill him for the future' and that Jeffries must be 'eliminated'.
The arrest highlights growing concerns about the safety of lawmakers amid a surge in threats, with Capitol Police reporting 14,000 threat assessments by end of 2025.
Moynihan had a prior criminal history, including a 2023 sentence of 21 months in prison and 36 months of supervised release for his role in the Capitol riot.
This incident underscores the controversy surrounding blanket pardons, with critics arguing that individuals with violent or criminal histories should not be released without increased oversight.

summaryOfNewsArticle: Christopher Moynihan, a man pardoned by former President Trump in early 2021 for his involvement in the January 6 Capitol riot, has been arrested in October 2025 on a charge of making a terroristic threat to U.S. House Minority Leader Hakeem Jeffries. Court documents reveal that Moynihan allegedly sent text messages threatening to kill Jeffries, including statements such as 'I will kill him for the future' and 'Even if I am hated he must be eliminated.' Moynihan, who had previously served 21 months in prison and 36 months of supervised release, was released under a pardon along with over 1,500 others. His arrest comes amid a dramatic rise in threats to lawmakers, with Capitol Police reporting approximately 14,000 threat assessments by the end of 2025. The case raises significant concerns about the impact of blanket pardons on public safety and the potential for individuals with prior violent criminal histories to reoffend, exemplified by the earlier death of Matthew Huttle, a pardoned defendant who was killed by law enforcement. This incident underscores the tension between executive clemency and national security.
title: Pardoned Capitol rioter arrested for allegedly threatening to kill Hakeem Jeffries
